awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Slow-Slip and Fluid Flow Response Offshore New Zealand -Probing The Nature Of The Margin Hydrogeochemical System
awd_abstract_narration:
Observations at subduction zones over the past two decades have revealed a range of modes by which stress is released on the plate boundary, including periodic slow slip behavior. Slow slip events occur at a rate intermediate between long-term tectonic plate motion and the fast slip velocity that occurs during earthquakes. Thus, slow slip is thought to span the transition between stable slip and the stick-slip process that generates earthquakes. An important mechanism that could cause the transitions in slip style is the evolution of pressure along the fault that is generated by the accumulation and release of fluids. There is a concerted and extensive international sampling and monitoring effort to understand slow slip at the Hikurangi margin offshore New Zealand. A missing piece in this effort is the sampling and monitoring of fluids along seafloor fault zones over a long enough period of time to capture a slip event. This project will address this problem and will provide a two-year continuous record of fluid flow rate and composition over the time frame of the next expected large slow slip event. The project will add value to other ongoing NSF-funded programs at this margin such as scientific ocean drilling and seismic surveys aimed at understanding slow slip events. From both the scientific and societal perspectives, results from this project will contribute to our understanding of earthquake activity not only offshore New Zealand but worldwide. This project has a large component of international collaboration. The project supports the training of graduate and undergraduate students. 



This project addresses the GeoPRISMS Program's Subduction Cycles and Deformation Initiative Science Plan by testing interrelationships between fluid production, fluid flow, and slow slip at the Hikurangi margin off New Zealand. At the Hikurangi margin, the recognition of dramatic changes in the along-strike depth distributions of slow-slip events (SSEs) and their recurrence intervals, interseismic coupling, inferred pore pressure, and other subduction-related parameters have resulted in a concerted international effort to acquire seismological, geodetic, other geophysical, and geomechanical data. This project will complement and extend these efforts by providing 1) a two-year continuous record of fluid flow rate and composition over the timeframe of the next expected large SSE; 2) information on the present background state of fluid flow and how it relates to inferred overpressure along the plate boundary; and 3) comparative geochemical and hydrologic data between the northern and southern sections of the margin. The work plan combines ship operations and Remotely Operated Vehicle (ROV) surveys in a nested approach to constrain the margin-wide fluid flow distribution. Coring, heat flow measurements, and benthic fluid flow meter deployments will target fault zones and off-fault locations from the deformation front to the shelf-break. Continuous fluid flow rate measurements at off-fault locations will quantify the fluid flow response to local volumetric strain during slip, and comparative data at fault zones will provide information on the hydrologic responses to slip.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding the mechanics of fault behavior at subduction zones, where one tectonic plate descends beneath another, is one of the most pressing issues for geoscientists today. Transient slow slip along the plate boundary appears to bridge the gap between typical earthquake behavior and steady, aseismic slip on faults, and is now recognized as an important frictional transition within the spectrum of processes that accommodate plate convergence at subduction zones. The overarching hypotheses for slow slip behavior center on the premise that slip on the plate interface is modulated by fluid pressure and sediment properties, with the corollary that fluid discharge at the seafloor is regulated by slip activity. The Hikurangi margin, offshore the east coast of New Zealand, was selected as a promising site to develop a process-based understanding of slow-slip in subduction zones. Missing from collective international efforts at Hikurangi subduction zone is the surface sampling and monitoring of fluid flow directly tied to fault zones spanning the deformation front to the shelf-edge and over periods of expected slip activity.

This project was aimed at testing the hypothesis that slip activity modulates fluid discharge at the seafloor by measuring heat flow and sampling of the fluids discharged at the seafloor along faults on the Hikurangi subduction zone, where past investigations have documented the occurrence slow-slip events and their recurrence intervals. As observed at other subduction margins, we expected to see evidence of fluids being rapidly expelled at fault zones, which serve as efficient flow paths from depth. Surprisingly, heat flow data and chemical composition of samples collected at sites of fluid emission on the Hikurangi margin do not show evidence for drainage. Overall, the heat flow data does not show anomalies that can be obviously ascribed to the discharge of warm fluids originating at depth. Similarly, the geochemical data is not consistent with deep-sourced fluids at any of our coring locations and furthermore, the shallowly-sourced fluids we sampled are expelled at very low flow rates ≤ 2 cm/yr, indicating the permeability at fault zone permeability is not significantly different from that of the sediment matrix.

These observations imply that fluids in the Hikurangi subduction zone have limited vertical drainage and are likely to be trapped at depth, causing high pore pressures along the plate boundary. Our results are consistent with published geochemical data along the Pāpaku Fault drilled at International Ocean Discovery program (IODP) Site U1518, and will complement ongoing seafloor and IODP borehole monitoring experiments that span slow slip episodes. Our results serve as the framework, which integrated with ongoing studies, will result in an enhanced understanding of the deformation and hydrological responses to slow slip at the Hikurangi subduction zone, with implications for other margins worldwide.


Last Modified: 11/01/2023
Modified by: Robert N Harris
